headline: CNN News Central
subHeadline: $100,000 Reward For Info In Birmingham Mass Shooting; Speaker Johnson Unveils New Plan To Avoid Government Shutdown; NASA Astronaut Tracy Dyson Back On Earth After 184 Days. Aired 1:30-2p ET

utterances.speaker: ANDREW MCCABE, CNN SENIOR LAW ENFORCEMENT ANALYST
utterances.sentences: So at this point, I don't think we have enough information to say that a ball was dropped here. But it'll be interesting to find out the full extent of what the government knows as this case goes forward.

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: Happening now in Birmingham, Alabama, Crimestoppers and the FBI are offering up to $100,000 for information in connection with a mass shooting there over the weekend.Multiple shooters fired into a group of people outside of a nightclub there in Birmingham in what police describe as a targeted hit. Four people killed, 17 others injured. CNN's Rafael Romo is in Birmingham following this for us. So, Rafael, in a press conference earlier today, officials said that the shooters were paid.

utterances.speaker: RAFAEL ROMO, CNN NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Yes, Brianna, that's one of key -- several key details that officials have revealed since the shooting.Birmingham police say the shooter -- the shooting was not random and stemmed from an isolated incident and were -- multiple victims were caught in the crossfire. In fact, Chief Scott Thurmond said he believes this was a targeted hit on one person and the other victims were caught in the crossfire. This is how the chief explained it earlier. Let's take a listen. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: CHIEF SCOTT THURMOND, BIRMINGHAM POLICE DEPARTMENT
utterances.sentences: There's just motivation from, as Carol mentioned, that, you know, some of the individuals that were killed have extensive criminal histories.And because of that, there's oftentimes motivation from others and there's people who are willing to pay to have them killed. And so that's -- that's part of it. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: ROMO
utterances.sentences: And, Brianna, Thurmond also said that multiple suspects fired upon a large group of people outside an establishment here in the Five Points South area on Saturday night just after 11And here's another key detail. Police say the shooters used what is believed to have been a gun conversion device that can be used to override the trigger mechanism on a gun so that it functions as a machine gun. That will explain the reason why police say more than 100 shell casings were collected here at the scene. Birmingham Mayor Randall Woodfin says the city is getting a lot of help from the FBI and the ATF as they continue the manhunt for the people responsible for the shooting.

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: Just one week to go before a government shutdown and House Speaker Mike Johnson is now pushing a new plan, one that would keep the government funded until December 20th.It includes an additional $230 million for Secret Service funding, but it does not include a Trump-backed measure requiring proof of citizenship to vote. This bill would punt the funding fight past Election Day and, of course, right before the holidays. But are they really close to a deal? We have CNN's Manu Raju live for us on Capitol Hill. I'll ask you, Manu. Are they close?

utterances.speaker: MANU RAJU, CNN CHIEF CONGRESSIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Yes, look, this is expected to pass Congress this week. We do expect a government shutdown to be avoided, but not until the speaker decided to essentially give Democrats what they had been asking for.Democrats had asked for -- to extend government funding for three months until mid-December. That's pretty much what speaker decided to do. He did it until December 20th. They also, the Democrats wanted it to be free of any extraneous provisions, namely that proposal that Donald Trump himself had been demanding two provide -- to demand proof of citizenship for people who are voting. An effort to try to clamp down on undocumented immigrants from voting in elections, something that's already illegal, but something that Trump and Mike Johnson, the speaker, both said was absolutely necessary. Now, because Johnson has dropped those provisions, he's gotten a lot of backlash from the right flank of his party. And I asked the chairman of the House Appropriations Committee about what some members on the right are calling a capitulation to Democrats. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: What do you say to folks in your conference who are concerned about a clean C.R.? They see this as a capitulation.REP. TOM COLE (R-OK): Well, it's not, frankly. You know, they all voted for it last week when -- or most of them, when it was coupled with the SAVE Act. We're sorry, but it was our own members that didn't -- didn't show up to do that. Look, there's no way, politically, a government shutdown on the eve of an election is good for us, not good for the president, not good for the Republican House majority. More importantly, is just not good for the country. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: A NASA astronaut is back on earth after spending 184 days in space. Tracy Dyson left the International Space Station early this morning, boarding a Soyuz capsule for the ride home.Here's the moment that she and two Russian cosmonauts parachute-landed in Kazakhstan. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Touch down. Right on the money. A textbook touchdown on the steppe of Kazakhstan.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Tracy Dyson is home after 184 days in space. Oleg Kononenko and Nikolai Chub are home after 374 days in space, a record for an International Space Station mission.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: CNN's Tom Foreman is with us now.Two things. One, that's like a harder landing -- (CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: -- than I was expecting. I'm like, oh --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: TOM FOREMAN, CNN CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: -- the way home.

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: Brace for impact.Tom -- (CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: FOREMAN
utterances.sentences: -- compared to the 1960s.

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: But also two of her friends delayed on the space station?

utterances.speaker: FOREMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Well, that continues.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: FOREMAN
utterances.sentences: You know, this is the Boeing Starliner crew, the two that went up in early June, June 5th.

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore.

utterances.speaker: FOREMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Exactly. So Williams and Wilmore, which kind of sound like a country band.But nevertheless -- (CROSSTALK) (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: FOREMAN
utterances.sentences: -- they're -- they're up there still. And they're going to remain there for right now. You may be saying, why are they remaining there? Because, with these flights going back and forth, they we're supposed to come back in a little over a week and they're stuck up there.The reason is basically this. Because their ride was canceled, in effect. They said, look, we're bringing back the Starliner craft with nobody on board because of the issues about helium and about thrusters and about the way it was -- the way it was approaching earth. And they wanted to make sure everything was OK, nobody got hurt. It was a safety call. But the way they assign seats up there is very complicated. There are deals between the U.S. and Russia negotiating on who gets on one of these flights like this from Russia or who gets on flights from the U.S. It's very involved. And you don't really upset that apple cart easily by saying just jump on the next flight. Plus, astronauts are prepared to stay for months and months. That's what makes them astronauts. They don't get mad about not coming home on time. They would rather stay longer. So that's a bonus.

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: I once worked in radio and there was a contest --(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: -- of how many people could stay for as long as possible in a Volkswagen Beetle.

utterances.speaker: FOREMAN
utterances.sentences: How'd that work out?

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: Well, it gets uncomfortable --(CROSSTALK) (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: -- which leads me --(LAUGHTER) FOREMAN: -- a concept, too, it's like going to a concert. But -- (CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: All right, so how many people -- you know, is it starting to get like that? Like how many people can the space station accommodate comfortably for how long?

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: Yes, like van life, like an R.V.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: An RV across the country.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: FOREMAN
utterances.sentences: -- California --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: FOREMAN
utterances.sentences: -- van life. You live here in California.

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm not. It's gets uncomfortable. I'm not about that life. (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: Tom Foreman. Tom Foreman, thank you very much.(CROSSTALK) (LAUGHTER)
